faq.title: Everything people ask before jumping in
faq.description: Short, honest answers we revisit every week with the community.

items.question: What do you call volunteering?
items.answer: A deliberate, time-bound commitment to serve the common good within a recognised structure, with mutual expectations spelled out.

items.question: Volunteering vs. benevolat?
items.answer: Volunteering involves a framed mission and shared accountabilities; benevolat stays informal, with no exclusivity or contractual duty.

items.question: NGO or association — what is the difference?
items.answer: NGOs can be national or international actors ranging from associations to foundations; a French association is any non-profit collective, with or without public-interest status.

items.question: Why be cautious with voluntourism?
items.answer: Because impact cannot be a souvenir. We prioritise community-led missions, safeguarding, and proof of need before any placement.

items.question: How do I find credible associations?
items.answer: Lean on vetted directories, local networks, and our own legitimacy checks — we call every project before publishing it.

items.question: How do you validate legitimacy?
items.answer: We request legal proof, on-the-ground references, financial transparency, and social presence before any match goes live.

items.question: Can someone help me choose?
items.answer: Yes. Book a 20-minute sparring session with our mission leads; we help you navigate visas, expectations, and the emotional load.

items.question: I don't want to go alone — can I find a buddy?
items.answer: Opt into the buddy programme and we introduce you to equally motivated volunteers leaving at the same time.

items.question: What if I prefer donating?
items.answer: We curate donation-ready projects and foundations; just let us know and we point you toward the right vehicle.

items.question: Is ambassador or sponsorship work possible?
items.answer: Absolutely. Select the ambassador track and we define storytelling, influence, and measurement frameworks together.

items.question: What about visas and procedures?
items.answer: Each mission pack lists visas, timelines, insurance, and travel notes; we update them weekly with partners on the ground.

items.question: Do you cover Service Civique?
items.answer: When a mission fits the Service Civique framework we highlight it and redirect you to the official platform.

items.question: What is Service Civique?
items.answer: A French public programme for 16-25 year olds (30 for participants with disabilities) offering paid missions that serve the public interest.

jeanne.title: Jeanne Brantus
jeanne.subtitle: Founder of N'GO Match & field reporter
paragraphs: My name is Jeanne Brantus, I am 26, and I grew up between the light of Corsica and the streets of Lyon. Very early on I wanted to understand what existed “elsewhere”. That curiosity pushed me to Togo, Benin, Tanzania, India, the Philippines... Places that teach you volunteering is not a trip—it is a meeting.

From mission to mission I discovered the questions volunteers keep, the real needs of associations, and the misunderstandings that sometimes separate both sides. That is when my conviction was born: we need a bridge—something simple, human, sincere.

With N'GO I use that experience to guide anyone who wants to engage and to give visibility to associations acting every day. Through Instagram and on-the-ground reports I share what I have seen, learned, and what communities entrusted to me.
My goal is simple: help everyone find their seat where they can truly serve.
